article.title: Cow_tipping

link.part: A healthy cow lying on its side is not immobilized; it can rise whenever it chooses.

article.paragraph: Cow tippingis the purported activity of sneaking up on any unsuspecting or sleeping uprightCattlecowand pushing it over for entertainment. The practice of cow tipping is generally considered anurban legend, and the implication that a cow can be pushed over and not stand up again is incorrect, as, unless injured, cows routinely lie down and can easily regain their footing. The implication thatRural arearuralcitizens seek such entertainment due to lack of other alternatives is also generally viewed as astereotype.cite newsWinterSam A.Who You Calling a Hick?: Treatise of a Disgruntled Kansanhttp://www.thecrimson.com/article/2003/3/6/who-you-calling-a-hick-i/28 December 2014The Harvard CrimsonMarch 6, 2003
article.heading: Scientific study
article.paragraph: The urban legend of cow tipping relies upon the presumption that cattle are slow-moving, dim-witted, and weak-legged, thus easily pushed over without much force. Some versions of the legend suggest that because cows sleep standing up, it is possible to approach them and push them over without the animals reacting.However, cows only sleep lightly while standing up, and they are easily awoken from this state.cite newsMalvernJackCow-tipping myth hasn't got a leg to stand onTimes Onlinehttp://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/uk/article1940322.ece2006-10-28LondonNovember 5, 2005http://web.archive.org/web/20110629083548/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article586737.ece2011-06-29yesFurthermore, numerous sources have questioned the practice's feasibility, since most cows weigh over half a ton, and easily resist any lesser force.cite webSemkeMattThe Statics of Cow TippingUNL College of Engineering and Mechanics Course Projecthttp://emweb.unl.edu/Mechanics-Pages/Matt-Semke/The%20Statics%20of%20Cow%20Tipping.htm2007-04-17

A 2005 study led by Margo Lillie, azoologyzoologistat theUniversity of British Columbia, concluded that tipping a cow would require an exertion of 2,910newtons(654.2lbflbf) of force,cite newsHainesLesterBoffins debunk cow-tipping mythThe Register9 November 200530 November 2012http://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/11/09/cow_tippingand is therefore impossible to accomplish by a single person. Her calculations found that it would take at least two people to apply enough force to push over a cow if the cow did not react and reorient its footing. If the cow did react, it would take at least four people to push it over. Lillie noted that cattle are well aware of their surroundings and are very difficult to surprise, due to excellent senses of both smell and hearing,Cite newsColebournJohnDebunking rural myth of cow tipping: It's udder nonsense, academics contendMontreal GazetteA10November 9, 2005Ian Denomme, "Cow-tipping a mooo-yth?",The Gazette(Western Daily Student Newspaper), November 9, 2005. (retrieved on January 12, 2009)Eddie Glenn, "Cow-tipping: Myth or reality?",Tahlequah Daily Press, December 15, 2006. (retrieved on January 12, 2009).but that according to laws of static physics, "two people might be able to tip a cow" if the cow were "tipped quicklythe cow'scentre of masswould have to be pushed over its hoof before the cow could react".cite newsHainesLesterBoffins debunk cow-tipping mythThe Register UK9 November 200530 November 2012http://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/11/09/cow_tippingThe Lillie study has beenReproducibilityreplicatedby other researchers, who confirmed that at least two to four people can, in fact, push over a cow.cite webSemkeMattThe Statics of Cow TippingUNL College of Engineering and Mechanics Course Projecthttp://emweb.unl.edu/Mechanics-Pages/Matt-Semke/The%20Statics%20of%20Cow%20Tipping.htm2007-04-17("According to these numbers, cow tipping is possible when two people are in on the prank.")

In 1255,Louis IX of FranceSandwich, Kent#Historygave an elephanttoHenry III of Englandfor hismenageriein theTower of London. Drawn from life by the historianMatthew Parisfor hisChronica Majora, it can be seen in hisbestiaryatParker LibraryofCorpus Christi College, Cambridge, with an accompanying text revealing that at the time, Europeans believed that elephants did not have knees and so were unable to get up if they fell over.
